comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article119000289 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16574218 ...going on these items, I suspect she might be 'Kono San', a "Japanese flapper"(!) singer/comedienne who appears to have been engaged by the Melbourne and Sydney Tivoli Theatres in later 1929. Some Australian newspapers have her name as 'Kone San' or 'Konasan'...the US newspaper items I've found all have 'Kono San' or 'Konosan'...per the Australian newspaper items, by 1929 she'd spent 5 years on the Keith vaudeville circuit in the US (which I gather was a US version of JC Williamson)...theatre experts might be able to tell us all about her...was she Japanese or a Japanese-American? Fascinating! fultonhistory.com/newspapers%20Disk3/Albany%20NY%20Evenin... (see 'At the Theatres') Ha! love the description..."Kono San is built on whippet lines" (!) ...short of more conclusive evidence emerging, that counts as a key clue! Might have to dig around in the yet to be digitised theatre magazines to find more info on her...note that one US reviewer referred to her as a "Chinese girl", however her name (and I assume it would have been a stage name) suggests she was Japanese... Just to wander slightly off track(!)...there were evidently quite a few Chinese and Chinese-American vaudeville stars in the US in the 1920s...eg. Anna Chang... softfilm.blogspot.com.au/2009/01/anna-chang-chinese-princ...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Fascinating! A flapper in our collection! Fantastic quasymody :) There's another blog there for sure. Interesting, that newspaper report saying she was Chinese, must have been them just assuming that was the case and getting it wrong. Wish we had a film like the Anna Chang one. I wonder where the Anna Chang one came from anyway. So exciting that I have been distracted for the past hour doing my own searches :)

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] ! fultonhistory.com/Newspaper4/Binghamton%20NY%20Press%20Gr... ...this 1930 Binghampton Press item describes her as "Japan's foremost flapper" (see final item in 'High Class Acts...') ...looks like she'd returned to the US by early 1930...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Hmmm, I get the sense that was their promo tactic. Unless of course she really was well known, and the records about her just haven't been digitised...Although I can't help but feel if she really was such a raging success, wouldn't the Australian newspapers have given her more of a mention?
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02/9667329561/]

Source: the Bulletin (Sydney), 4 September, 1929 (p. 16).

'Kono San, the Japanese nightingale' (!)...I'm  98% convinced it's her...in the Bulletin pic she appears to be wearing the same aviator cap...possibly the same unfortunate fox too!

I'd say she was a fairly minor stage figure...the various newspaper items suggest she did a short 15 minute or so variety show routine.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] I don't think flappers gained universal approval in Australia either (!)

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] I think it must be her, after all, how many Japanese flappers did they have on that one ship at that particular time? I love the risque element to it all, what a fascinating discovery :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article131641404 - another pic...this one is from the recently digitised Sunday Times, 1 September, 1929...looks like her hat was a fixture...
